What is an Environmental Engineer?

Environmental Engineers are engineers that use their training and knowledge of engineering principles to develop solutions to environmental issues. Their focuses range from waste to public health to air pollution.

Where does an Environmental Engineer work?

  • State, local, or federal government
  • Urban and regional planning offices
  • Specific outdoor sites

How much does an Environmental Engineer make?

Based on real new grad salaries reported through Handshake, the median annual salary for an Environmental Engineer is $55,718.

What majors are typically interested in becoming Environmental Engineers?

One’s major doesn’t necessarily determine their career, but these are some common majors of those who end up pursuing environmental engineering jobs.

  • Environmental engineering majors
  • General engineering majors
  • Environmental science majors
Explore Environmental Engineering job opportunities on Handshake.

Environmental Engineers skills and competencies:

On top of a relevant degree and formal training, here are some professional skills that can help aspiring Environmental Engineers succeed in their work:

  • Strong analytical skills
  • Background in science
  • Strong technical engineering skills

What are some common questions about Environmental Engineers?

Q: How do I become an Environmental Engineer?

A: When deciding to follow the environmental path of engineering, it’s key to have knowledge of the nature of the environment and how it works. Not only is theoretical knowledge and technical knowledge important to have, but all the other moving parts that play into the environment. Definitely get hands-on experience and learn as much as you can from professors, mentors, and coworkers.
